awd_titl_txt: Research on Optimizing Testing Feedback for Improved Student Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
General chemistry is often taught in large lecture sections, which can influence an instructor's choice to utilize multiple-choice exams and limit the testing feedback students receive. This project will build on prior work (DUE Awards #1140351 and #1140914) to further understand the best ways provide feedback to students and to help instructors employ best practices that maximize student learning through testing. Based on existing research in cognitive science, this project will collect evidence on current practices of testing feedback in general chemistry and measure the impacts on student learning of various forms of feedback with a diverse set of student populations. Findings from this work will be applicable to general chemistry programs across the nation as well as other STEM disciplines that utilize complex content items in multiple-choice testing. Developing and using evidence-based strategies to enhance and support student learning is a critical step in producing a well-prepared and diverse STEM workforce.

This project aims to generate evidence regarding the role of testing feedback to promote and support learning in general chemistry. It will pursue three related sets of studies. Laboratory and classroom testing feedback studies will examine the impact of different corrective feedback types and timings on future test performance and confidence-accuracy calibration. Qualitative testing feedback studies will employ semi-structured interviews to reveal how students use feedback in a testing environment and how this feedback may affect their learning, testing strategies, and confidence. Lastly, a national survey will be developed and administered to examine instructors' testing feedback practices and perceptions in first-term general chemistry to better connect theory developed through this project with current practices. The results of this work will generate evidence for selecting and using testing feedback with a goal of using multiple-choice testing as a learning tool as well as an evaluation tool.

por.por_cntn:
This grant brought together a diverse team of chemistry education researchers and a psychology education researcher from different institutional cultures to investigate the efficacy of testing feedback for supporting and promoting student learning within the context of general chemistry. In addition, the project offered workforce training for 1 statistician, 1 chemistry instructor, 1 postdoctoral researcher, 3 graduate students, and 17 undergraduate students. Through our work, we provided evidence to support a shift in teaching and learning culture from testing for just evaluation to testing for both evaluation (a teacher-centered approach) and formative assessment (a student-centered approach). This project began with a NSF TUES (DUE 1140914) grant which established proof of concept for methodology to collect repetitive testing data in general chemistry. This work expanded and continued into this multifaceted IUSE grant. The grant outcomes included the following: validation of a set of cloned exams for repetitive testing studies in general chemistry; generation of a large, diverse data set for the development and validation of new partial credit scoring methodologies and estimates of the impacts of various types of feedback on cloned test performance; development of feasible classroom testing feedback practices using classroom management systems; utilization of qualitative think aloud interviews to capture student response process changes through testing with feedback; and design and implementation of a national survey on testing feedback practices and perceptions in general chemistry.

This project reached a broad community of students and faculty from around the country including two large urban universities, a Hispanic serving university, a small and a medium rural primarily undergraduate university, a military service academy, and a professional school. The practice testing feedback study data set consisted of around 2000 volunteer General Chemistry I students from across these university types who participated in repetitive testing studies outside of their course time whereby the testing feedback was altered during week 1 of testing (immediate corrective feedback) and/or between week 1 and 2 of testing (delayed corrective feedback) with 11 different possible treatments. The qualitative think aloud studies involved around 100 students from 3 different universities. The classroom feasibility studies were conducted at 1 institution across six different terms of general chemistry with follow-up student surveys. Not only did large study populations  help support more generalizable project claims, it also increased our broader impacts by adding testing feedback to the teaching and learning conversation in general chemistry. The national testing feedback survey received responses from faculty who taught general chemistry within the past five years (511 responses, ~12% response rate) at universities with highest degrees of Associates, Bachelors, Masters and Doctoral chemistry degrees. The national survey identified mismatches between common testing feedback practices and our project findings. Having students retake the exam and receive item by item feedback with and without elaboration was beneficial to support student learning.

We hope that the results of this grant provide chemistry educators with effective ways to provide feedback on multiple-choice exams as a way to enhance their use in student learning rather just as summative assessments. We also anticipate that our project results will be more broadly applicable to other STEM disciplines that utilize similar question problem solving as found in general chemistry exams.
